rsbNotes.title: Ps 53
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 53 Cf. Ps. 14. A meditation on the wickedness of the fool. God will destroy the fool and restore Israel’s fortunes. Ps. 53, in contrast to Ps. 14, uses “God” rather than the more specific, covenant “Lord” to refer to the deity. This variation fits the broader context, since Ps. 53 is in Book II of the Psalter, which uses the broader term rather than the covenant name.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 53:1–4
rsbNotes.text: 53:1–4 See notes Ps. 14:1–4.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 53:5
rsbNotes.text: 53:5 scatters the bones. In the Old Testament God often fights for His people against their flesh-and-blood enemies. With New Testament revelation the underlying spiritual conflict to save His people from sin becomes the dominant theme, although the real conflict has been at this level from the beginning (Gen. 3:4, 5).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 53:6
rsbNotes.text: 53:6 salvation for Israel. An expression of hope for deliverance from evil.
